Well, the whole concept of sub-groups is a very contentious one in science, at least among epidemiologists.
The idea is, if you're doing a study and you want to see an effect, you have to design the study for what you want to see.
That way you know how many people you need in each group, you know what data you need to collect.

If, instead, you collect a whole bunch of data and then you go back and look, let's see, we didn't see a big effect in the big group, let's look at different age groups, or let's look at different ethnic groups, or let's look at this or that.
A lot of scientists think that's not a good way to go about it, because, one of the ways they do these, one of the criteria they use, is something called a confidence interval.
And the deal with a confidence interval, or a good statistical number, is there a 95% chance that this is right, meaning is there a 5% percent chance this is wrong?
We'll accept it.
If you measure 100 things, and they all could, five of them are going to be wrong, right off the bat, by your definition.
